title: Synthetic Recap
body:
INDIANAPOLIS — On a night defined by defensive grit and offensive struggle, Reggie Miller authored a masterpiece of scoring efficiency, carrying the Indiana Pacers to a decisive 92-78 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics.

While the final score suggests a defensive battle, this was the Reggie Miller Show. The sharpshooter was simply transcendent, pouring in a game-high 42 points in a performance that left the Sonics searching for answers. Miller’s offense was a study in surgical precision, slicing through Seattle’s defense from all angles.

The Pacers’ victory was built upon Miller’s historic individual effort, but he was not alone. Rik Smits provided a crucial interior presence, adding 14 points and a team-high 10 rebounds for a double-double. The Pacers’ defense, however, was the perfect complement to Miller’s fireworks, holding the high-powered Sonics to a paltry 78 points.

Seattle’s offense never found its rhythm. Gary Payton, despite dishing out 10 assists, was held to just 13 points on inefficient shooting. Vin Baker managed a team-high 16 points, but it was a quiet 16, lost in the shadow of Miller’s brilliance. The Sonics, as a team, shot a frigid 37% from the field, a testament to the relentless defensive pressure applied by Indiana.

In the end, the narrative was singular and undeniable: Reggie Miller. On a night where baskets were a premium for everyone else, Miller was a flamethrower in a sea of ice. His 42-point explosion not only secured the win but served as a stunning reminder of his ability to take over a game and dominate the biggest stage.
